metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XPath Nodes
XPath Terminology
Nodes
In XPath, there are seven kinds of nodes: element, attribute, text, namespace, processing-instruction, comment, and root nodes.
content.html: In XPath, there are seven kinds of nodes: element, attribute, text, namespace, processing-instruction, comment, and root nodes.

content.text: XML documents are treated as trees of nodes. The topmost element of the tree is called the root element.
content.html: XML documents are treated as trees of nodes. The topmost element of the tree is called the root element.

content.text: Look at the following XML document:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<bookstore>
 
<book>

<title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>

<author>J K. Rowling</author>



<year>2005</year>

<price>29.99</price>


</book>
</bookstore>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<bookstore>
  <book>
    <title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>
    <author>J K. Rowling</author>
    <year>2005</year>
    <price>29.99</price>
  </book>
</bookstore>

content.text: Example of nodes in the XML document above:
content.html: Example of nodes in the XML document above:

content.code:
<bookstore>  (root element node)


<author>J K. Rowling</author>  (element node)


lang="en" (attribute node)
content.code_html:
<bookstore> (root element node)

<author>J K. Rowling</author> (element node)

lang="en" (attribute node)

content.text: Atomic values
Atomic values are nodes with no children or parent.
content.html: Atomic values are nodes with no children or parent.

content.text: Example of atomic values:
Items
Items are atomic values or nodes.
Relationship of Nodes
Parent
Each element and attribute has one parent.
content.html: Each element and attribute has one parent.

content.text: In the following example; the book element is the parent of the title, author, year, and price:
content.html: In the following example; the book element is the parent of the title, author, year, and price:

content.code_html:
<book>
  <title>Harry Potter</title>
  <author>J K. Rowling</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>29.99</price>
</book>

content.text: Children
Element nodes may have zero, one or more children.
content.html: Element nodes may have zero, one or more children.

content.text: In the following example; the title, author, year, and price elements are all children of the book element:
content.html: In the following example; the title, author, year, and price elements are all children of the book element:

content.code_html:
<book>
  <title>Harry Potter</title>
  <author>J K. Rowling</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>29.99</price>
</book>

content.text: Siblings
Nodes that have the same parent.
In the following example; the title, author, year, and price elements are all siblings:
content.html: In the following example; the title, author, year, and price elements are all siblings:

content.code_html:
<book>
  <title>Harry Potter</title>
  <author>J K. Rowling</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>29.99</price>
</book>

content.text: Ancestors
A node's parent, parent's parent, etc.
In the following example; the ancestors of the title element are the book element and the bookstore element:
content.html: In the following example; the ancestors of the title element are the book element and the bookstore element:

content.code_html:
<bookstore>

<book>
  <title>Harry Potter</title>
  <author>J K. Rowling</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>29.99</price>
</book>

</bookstore>

content.text: Descendants
A node's children, children's children, etc.
In the following example; descendants of the bookstore element are the book, title, author, year, and price elements:
content.html: In the following example; descendants of the bookstore element are the book, title, author, year, and price elements:

content.code_html:
<bookstore>

<book>
  <title>Harry Potter</title>
  <author>J K. Rowling</author>
  <year>2005</year>
  <price>29.99</price>
</book>

</bookstore>
